Jobs to be Done (Epic Description): As a student, I want fast, efficient and streamlined authentication, not needing to login again if I have already logged-in on this or other University systems, so that I only need to log-in once and I can stay focused and productive without login friction.
User Story Description: As a student using Okta FastPass, I want to log in passwordlessly through the Okta app so that I don’t need to repeat MFA or manually enter my credentials.
Acceptance Criteria:
When FastPass is available, the login flow automatically redirects to Okta FastPass verification.
FastPass satisfies MFA requirements without additional user action.
Login completes without entering username or password.
If FastPass is unavailable or fails, the system falls back to username + password + MFA (Okta Verify).
Users can still choose alternative login methods when FastPass isn’t appropriate.

User Story Description: As a student who has set up a Passkey, I want to log in using device-stored secure credentials so that I can authenticate quickly without typing my username or password.
Acceptance Criteria:
When a Passkey is detected, the system initiates Passkey authentication automatically.
The username associated with the Passkey is prefilled before the authentication flow begins.
Successful Passkey authentication logs the user in without entering username or password.
If Passkey authentication fails or the user cancels, the system falls back to traditional login (username + password).
Users can opt out of using Passkey and choose another method.
Technology: Okta Identity Cloud (FastPass configuration), Okta Verify App.

Jobs to be Done (Epic Description): As a student, I want fast, efficient and streamlined authentication, not needing to login again if I have already logged-in on this or other University systems, so that I only need to log-in once and I can stay focused and productive without login friction.
User Story Title: Persist login state in one same session
User Story Description: As a student, I want my authenticated session to persist while moving between authenticated and unauthenticated content within the University ecosystem, so I’m not logged out unexpectedly.
Acceptance Criteria:
A valid authenticated session remains active while navigating between every authenticated pages and unauthenticated (public) pages within University-managed domains.
Returning to an authenticated page during an active session does not require re-login.
Session persists as long as the user does not log out and the session has not expired.
If the session expires, the system prompts the user to re-authenticate.

Jobs to be Done (Epic Description): As a student, I want fast, efficient and streamlined authentication, not needing to login again if I have already logged-in on this or other University systems, so that I only need to log-in once and I can stay focused and productive without login friction.
User Story Description: As a student, I want my username to be remembered on this browser so that logging in again is faster, unless I deliberately log in with a different account.
Acceptance Criteria:
When “Remember me” is selected, the username is stored in a browser cookie.
On the next visit, the login page automatically pre-fills the stored username.
If a preferred login method (e.g., Passkey / FastPass) is available, the system prompts that method first; otherwise prefilled username and password fields are shown.
If the user logs in with a different valid username, the stored username updates to this new value.
Username is only remembered on the specific browser/device where it was saved.
Technology: Session Management Service (Portal/CMS infra), Okta (Token management).

Jobs to be Done (Epic Description): As a student, I want to access my centralised University information from my mobile so I can receive important and timely updates while on the move. When systems aren’t mobile-friendly, I experience friction, delays, and frustration.
User Story Description: As a student, I want to access a fully responsive, mobile-optimised version of the portal through my mobile browser so that I can complete all essential tasks with the same functionality as desktop, following mobile-first UX best practice.
Acceptance Criteria:
The entire portal is accessible through modern mobile browsers (iOS/Android).
All desktop features are available on mobile with no functional limitations.
Layout adapts fluidly across common mobile screen sizes and orientations.
Mobile-first best practices are applied.
No horizontal scrolling is required except for purposeful components (e.g., tables).
All forms, interactions, and workflows function correctly in mobile browsers.
Accessibility is maintained on mobile (WCAG-compliant interactions, colours, focus states).
Technology: Content Management System (Responsive FE Framework eg. React/Next.js).

Jobs to be Done (Epic Description): As a student, I want to access my centralised University information from my mobile so I can receive important and timely updates while on the move. When systems aren’t mobile-friendly, I experience friction, delays, and frustration.
User Story Description: As a student, I want a dedicated native mobile app that provides faster performance, secure login via biometrics, and funtionalities that's reasonable under mobile context, so I can access essential university information and services in a seamless, device-integrated experience.
Acceptance Criteria:
A native app is available for iOS and Android.
The app supports secure authentication using device biometrics (FaceID/TouchID/Fingerprint).
The app uses existing infrastructure for push notifications.
The app features selected key experiences tailored to common mobile usage scenarios.
Critical alerts can be delivered via push notifications when the user opts in.
App maintains session securely using mobile standards (e.g., secure device storage).
Accessibility requirements are met (native screen reader support, contrast, tap targets).

If a user logs in successfully from the landing page, they are directed to the authenticated dashboard.

User Story Description: As a student, I want access to a single global search portal that lets me find content across key university systems, so I can quickly locate information without switching between platforms.
Acceptance Criteria:
Search is always visible and accessible to all users (authenticated or not).
Search spans multiple University systems: students.unimelb, Handbook, Library, and other relevant platforms.
Users can filter results by category, content type, or source system.
Users can sort results based on relevance, date, or popularity.
Search interface is mobile-first and responsive.
Search flow should follows UX best practices, including clear input, feedback, and accessibility compliance.
Search algorithm should be optimised and showing results that match with importance and students expectation.

User Story Description: As a student, I want search results prioritised according to my cohort and profile so that the most relevant content for my course, faculty, and level appears first.

Technology: Search Engine (Funnelback), Tealium (CDP), CMS (Content tagging), OneCRM (Student Attributes).

"Smooth student transition with tutorials and in-context help previews"
As a student, I want help content that smooths the transition from the old portal to the new version, so that I can learn the new system at a convenient time.
User Story Title: Allow users to decide when to switch to updated portal versions
User Story Description: As a student, I want the option to switch between the old and new portal versions so that I can explore updates at my own pace and adjust when I transition to the new system.
Acceptance Criteria:
On first login after a major update, a modal appears allowing the student to switch to the new portal version.
The modal provides hints about new features and an option to watch the tutorial.
Students can switch back and forth between old and new portal versions at any time from a consistent interface.
Students can skip the tutorial if they wish.
The old portal version is removed after a predetermined duration.
Default behaviour encourages switching to the new version but respects student choice.
Functionality is mobile-first and accessible on all supported devices.

User Story Title: Accessing Stop 1 with guided support and triage
User Story Description: As a student requiring assistance, I want a guided support experience that helps me self-diagnose and resolve my issue through recommended resources before presenting contact options, So that I can get the fastest possible resolution to my problem without waiting in a queue or submitting unnecessary administrative tickets.
Acceptance Criteria:
The student portal acts as a smart triage layer between the student and the University’s support teams (e.g., Stop 1). Rather than a static list of phone numbers, the "Contact Support" flow is an interactive sequence. It first attempts to resolve the student's intent using Knowledge Base articles, FAQs, or direct links to service pages. If self-resolution fails, the system presents the specific communication channels (Enquiry Form, Phone, Booking, Walk-in) relevant to that specific topic and the student’s current profile status.

1. Contextual Entry Points
The "Get Help" flow can be initiated from a global "Help & Support" centre.

Contextual "Need Help?" links appear on specific functional pages (e.g., an "Enrolment Support" link on the Study Plan page).

Contextual links pre-select the triage category based on the page the user is currently viewing to reduce friction.

2. Topic Triage & Intelligent Deflection
Upon initiating the flow, the user is prompted to select a category/topic (if not already pre-selected) or describe their issue (keyword search).

Before showing contact details, the system displays a "Recommended for you" section containing:

Relevant knowledge base articles (e.g., "How to apply for an extension").

Direct links to self-solve transaction pages (e.g., "Apply for Special Consideration" form).

The user must interact with a "Did this solve your issue?" or "I still need help" mechanism to proceed to contact channels.

3. Dynamic Channel Presentation
Once the user confirms they still require assistance, the system displays only the contact channels valid for that specific inquiry type:

Submit Enquiry: Opens the specific web form for that topic (eg. integrated with Salesforce Case Management).

Phone: Displays the specific support line number and current opening hours.

Appointments: Displays a "Book Appointment" button if the service offers consultations (e.g., Course Planning).

Walk-in: Displays physical location (Stop 1) and current queue/wait times if available.

4. Enquiry Capture & Handoff
If "Submit Enquiry" is selected, the form pre-fills known student data (Name, ID, Course).

The subject/topic selected during triage is automatically applied to the case to ensure correct routing to backend teams.

Upon submission, the student receives immediate on-screen confirmation and a Case Reference Number for tracking in their "Tasks and Enquiries".

User Story Description: As an international student, I want a centralised view of my visa status, Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) details, and compliance requirements, So that I can ensure I remain in the country legally, meet my study conditions, and apply for extensions on time without stress.
Acceptance Criteria:
1. Cohort-Specific Visibility (Personalisation)

The "Student Visa" section or widget is only visible to students identified as "International" or "Temporary Visa Holders" in their student profile.

For domestic students, this category is hidden or replaced by "Government Support (HECS-HELP)" to maintain relevance.

2. Critical Date Monitoring & Alerts (CoE & Visa)

The page displays the student’s current Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) end date and Visa Expiry Date (sourced from the student system record).

Target State Feature: A "Compliance Traffic Light" system visually alerts the student:

Green: Valid and compliant.

Amber: Visa/CoE expiring within 3–6 months (Prompt: "Plan your renewal").

Red: Urgent action required (Prompt: "Contact Stop 1 immediately").

3. Direct Action: CoE Extension & Renewal

Students can initiate a "Request CoE Extension" directly from this page.

The workflow provides a checklist of required supporting documents (e.g., intervention strategy, letter of progress) before the student clicks "Apply," reducing incomplete applications.

Deep-links to the Department of Home Affairs are provided for the actual visa renewal application, with a clear "You are leaving the University portal" disclaimer.

4. Visa Conditions & Work Rights Information

The section provides plain-language summaries of key visa conditions specific to the student's current status (e.g., "Work limitations: 48 hours per fortnight").

Includes a "Letter of Enrolment" generator that students can download instantly to prove their student status to employers or landlords.


5. Secure Document Storage
Students can securely upload and store their latest Visa Grant Notice or Bridging Visa documents in their profile.

The student should later be able to use uploaded documents for future university forms (e.g., internships or exchange applications) without re-uploading.
